awd_titl_txt: Stable Matching of Service Tours to Design Cooperative Policies for Transport Infrastructure Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Transportation technologies have reached a point where they can no longer be evaluated as systems in isolation. Urban travel options have become increasingly abundant in today's age of ubiquitous data and information and communications technologies: e.g. ridesharing, vehicle/bike sharing, and demand-responsive transit. Coordination of mobility solutions between multiple agencies during disasters and large scale incidents is increasingly more challenging. The solution in this study involves a careful reexamination of the supply-demand assignment models for transportation networks. It combines stable matching theory with network analysis for transformative impacts on transportation planning and game theory as applied to infrastructure systems. Policy-makers will be able to design cooperative policies with different transport operators, such as fare bundling, service leasing, asset co-location, to further encourage partnerships like that of Kansas City and Bridj. The same methodology can be used for risk pooling of resources in planning for disasters. The project will support training of a number of graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 STEM students from under-represented minorities in transportation systems and game theory. It will drive innovation and entrepreneurship by defining new functional roles in transportation planning that would engage with startup companies and incubators.

The study is split into two research thrusts. The first focuses on development of the core theory, which includes model formulation and algorithm development for traffic assignment as a many-to-one stable matching assignment game. Doing so would no longer assume that the transportation supply is fixed as in current methods. The model is then expanded to a many-to-many game to involve multiple operators so that cooperative policies between them can be evaluated. The second thrust focuses on applications of the theory, two of which are shared mobility systems and risk pooling strategies in disaster management. Customizations of the model to handle shared mobility services allow policymakers to evaluate specific shared mobility services like bike sharing or shared taxis. When the model is considered under uncertainty, cooperative strategies between multiple operators can be designed to pool risks together to minimize their impacts on individual operators. The study challenges over 60 years of research in transport modeling as an alternative theory of supply-demand interaction that considers both traveler and operator behavior.

por.por_cntn:
Transportation has seen a surge of emerging mobility services operating within the regulatory environment imposed by public agencies acting as facilitators--what practitioners are calling "Mobility-as-a-Service". As transportation is a public good, field evaluation of new systems is prohibitively costly, while prior transportation network analysis theories for modeling these systems generally lack the ability to explicitly consider how multiple coexisting operators might compete or collaborate to serve travelers. One of the defining works of this research is the development of a unified theory that expands cooperative game theory--stable matching--to evaluate how transportation networks owned by multiple operators with explicit capacity constraints match to travelers.  

The theory shifts analysis from analysis of single operators' networks to platforms of multiple operators. It allows platform operators (both private and public) to evaluate policies or operator technologies that impact the system by shifting costs from users to operators (e.g. fare discounts) or vice versa (adding more wait time or detouring to users to reduce operator costs). A public agency can use this theory to evaluate the impact of a new firm entry into a mobility market or when two firms merge, measure the effect that a surchage or tax may have on a market of multiple operators, or assess the impact that a breakdown of one operator's route may have on other operators. The theory was successfully proven in practice in a case study with a real microtransit platform in Luxembourg, showing the instability of a service that eventually shut down. 

The research makes transformative contributions to the emerging field of Mobility-as-a-Service and broadens the applicability of the field of cooperative game theory. The method was further applied to the field of disaster management in defining a new contract design that mobility operators can adopt with each other to agree to share their resources (line capacity, vehicles, etc.) in the event of a disaster to maintain overall resiliency. This should have profound effects on disaster planning between multiple agencies by allowing them to better coordinate with one another and involve private mobility companies in their planning. 

Findings from this research contributed to the Shared Electric Automated Mobility (SEAM) governance toolkit developed by the World Economic Forum. The knowledge contributed to supporting New York State Department of Transportation in their ongoing development of their next statewide mobility service program and to the Federal Transit Administration in learning more about microtransit and shared mobility services. The project helped the PI garner a Tier-1 University Transportation Center, C2SMART, based at NYU, along with a state on-call agreement with NY State. Three PhD students were supported as well as several MS, undergraduate, and K-12 students, which included several minority and women students. The research also made its way to graduate and undergraduate courses taught by the PI at NYU.
